text:
I set my webbrowser’s mono font to JuliaMono, because i wanted it for DexLang’s notebook-thing, which has basically no styling and so uses what the browser has set.
I am (pleasantly?) surprised just how many websites don’t specify their mono font; and so hit that.

text: I checked out Dex lang sort of recently. Seems really experimental but neat, what draws you too it? It looks promising for high performance numerical stuff

elements.text: I checked out Dex lang sort of recently. Seems really experimental but neat, what draws you too it? It looks promising for high performance numerical stuff

text:
It’s  super experimental and kinda broken all the time.
(like right now there are 2 bugs making it unusably slow for me)

elements.text:
It’s  super experimental and kinda broken all the time.
(like right now there are 2 bugs making it unusably slow for me)

text:
A few things.
• Julia got boring when things stopped breaking every 6-12 months.
• It has a nice-enough static type system
• Everyone involved in it is really smart and interesting, and its one of the only places to see their ideas that isn’t python.

elements.text: Julia got boring when things stopped breaking every 6-12 months.
It has a nice-enough static type system
Everyone involved in it is really smart and interesting, and its one of the only places to see their ideas that isn’t python.

text: Plus if this whole julia thing doesn’t workout, I should know a second programming language.

elements.text: Plus if this whole julia thing doesn’t workout, I should know a second programming language.

text: Don't you already know like 20 languages? :wink: Static typing has it's appeal that for sure. Interesting, well I'll try to at least follow it. Something tells me Julia was broken all the time in the early days too.

elements.text: Don't you already know like 20 languages?
Static typing has it's appeal that for sure. Interesting, well I'll try to at least follow it. Something tells me Julia was broken all the time in the early days too.

text:
No, I only know Dex and Julia.
I used to know 20 languages, but I have forgotten them all.
It’s really embarrassing.

elements.text:
No, I only know Dex and Julia.

It’s really embarrassing.

text: I'm kind of in the same boat, like I can pick up python(because its basically Julia Light), and I can scribble away at C++, C# and Java, but nothings fluid anymore. I've been picking up golang lately, it's really easy to learn. Not so nice for numerical stuff though :disappointed:. I think Julia's gonna be okay long term, but I bet pretty much everyone has their doubts from time to time.

elements.text: I'm kind of in the same boat, like I can pick up python(because its basically Julia Light), and I can scribble away at C++, C# and Java, but nothings fluid anymore. I've been picking up golang lately, it's really easy to learn. Not so nice for numerical stuff though
. I think Julia's gonna be okay long term, but I bet pretty much everyone has their doubts from time to time.

text:
I think that any skill you (or at least I) haven’t used in 6 months might as well be something you read a really in-depth blog post on.
Sure I used to write giant piles of python, C#, F# but now I can basically cobble together a loop after a few tries and looking at the docs.
Even more more the longer.
I legitimately failed to write helloworld in F#. F# used to be my favourite language.

text: same story. I have no idea how some dev's can hop from JS, to Scala, to python instantaneously. I guess you just have to constantly be using them

text: Cool! I use a neat Safari extension called Cascadea, which injects CSS font specifications into web pages. A few sites, notably github, don't let you swap fonts, but many do. Very useful for testing....
